snippet: Will Georgia's hard-hitting ads push families with obesity problems toward help, or toward anger and denial?
abstract: Will Georgia's hard-hitting ads push families with obesity problems toward help, or toward anger and denial?
lead_paragraph: The blogosphere hates Georgia's tough new Strong4Life campaign against childhood obesity. Short ads or billboards, each featuring an obese child (the youngest looks to be about 9, the oldest a teenager), tell Georgia to "stop sugarcoating" the problem. "Fat kids become fat adults," reads the slogan under what looks to be the youngest child, a little girl who can be seen in a brief video saying she hates to go to school, where kids make fun of her. Another ad, under a young boy, reads: "Big bones didn't make me this way. Big meals did."

headline.main: Georgia's Tough Campaign Against Childhood Obesity
